title: Fourier Analysis with Engineering Applications
requirements:
Prerequisite: MATH1510
Not for students who have taken ENGG2030, ESTR2206, ESTR2302, ESTR2360 or IERG2051.
description: The course covers Linear-time Invariant Systems, Convolution, Dirac delta functions, Fourier Analysis of Continuous and Discrete-time Systems, Sampling Theorem, Fast-Fourier Transform, Laplace Transform, Z-Transform, and Fourier uncertainty principle. There will be emphasis on the interplay between mathematical ideas in MATH courses and engineering applications. Ideas such as inner product spaces, Contour integration, Cauchy-Schwartz inequality, Spectral decomposition, etc. will be employed for obtaining various results.
outcome: Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to: 1. Appreciate the use of linearity and spectral decomposition as analysis tools 2. Recognize the power of working in transform domains – to take advantage of complementary insights 3. Recognize the power of mathematical ideas in obtaining engineering applications 4. Analyze Signals and LTI systems using: Fourier Transform, Laplace Transform, Z-transform 5. Perform convolution operation 6. Appreciate the significance of Fast Fourier Transform, Sampling theorem, etc. in engineering applications
syllabus: The course covers Linear-time Invariant Systems, Convolution, Dirac delta functions, Fourier Analysis of Continuous and Discrete-time Systems, Sampling Theorem, Fast-Fourier Transform, Laplace Transform, Z-Transform, and Fourier uncertainty principle. There will be emphasis on the interplay between mathematical ideas in MATH courses and engineering applications. Ideas such as inner product spaces, Contour integration, Cauchy-Schwartz inequality, Spectral decomposition, etc. will be employed for obtaining various results.  The course syllabus may be updated from year to year.
recommended_readings: ‘Signals and Systems’ – Oppenheim,Willsky Notes of Stanford Course EE251 – Fourier Analysis and Applications

title: Discrete Structures and Probability
requirements:
Prerequisite: MATH1050
Not for students who have taken CSCI2110, ENGG2430, ENGG2440, ENGG2450, ENGG2460, ENGG2470, ENGG2760, ESTR2002, ESTR2004, ESTR2005, ESTR2010, ESTR2012, ESTR2018, ESTR2308, ESTR2362, IERG2470 or MATH3280.
description: The course covers the following two related topics. Discrete Structures: Graphs, Combinatorics - sums and asymptotics, recurrences, counting Probability: Random Variables and Probability density functions, conditional probability, independence, expectations, Markov and Chebychev inequalities, laws of large numbers, Random Walks, basic Markov Chains.
outcome: Upon successful completion of the course, the students will have acquired the ability to: 1. Appreciate graphical representations and their utility 2. Appreciate various counting techniques and the power of mathematical induction 3. Understand probabilistic concepts and laws of large numbers 4. Use the above tools to estimate and solve problems
syllabus: The course covers the following two related topics.  Discrete Structures: Graphs, Combinatorics - sums and asymptotics, recurrences, counting Probability: Random Variables and Probability density functions, conditional probability, independence, expectations, Markov and Chebychev inequalities, laws of large numbers, Random Walks, basic Markov Chains. The course syllabus may be updated from time to time.
